awd_titl_txt: The Physical Conditions in Extreme Star Forming Regions in the ALMA Era
awd_abstract_narration:
Super Star Clusters (SSCs) are very large regions of active star formation that are thought to be the precursors to globular clusters of stars.  They typically contain a number of young massive stars surrounded by regions of ionized hydrogen gas (H II) and dust.  The dust surrounding the SSCs typically obscures the H II regions and stars from the visible part of the spectrum.  Observations of SSCs are, therefore, usually performed at wavelengths from the radio to infrared.   The goal of this proposal is to investigate the physical conditions that give rise to SSCs through a program of observations using the Atacama Large Millimeter/Sub-millimeter Array (ALMA) and the Jansky Very Large Array (JVLA).   

SSCs represent one of the most extreme modes of star formation in the universe.  The PI proposes to find and study the molecular cloud regions that are the pre-cursors to these SSCs.  The PI will use radio (JVLA) and sub-millimeter/millimeter (ALMA) data already in hand to study proto-SSCs found in the blue compact dwarf galaxy Henize 2-10 and the overlap region in the merging Antennae galaxies.  In addition, the PI will propose new observations to search for new SSC precursors within these two sources and in other galaxy systems.

The proposal will allow the PI to continue an excellent program of public outreach developed as part of a prior NSF award.  The program entitled "Dark Skies, Bright Kids" (DSBK) is an 8-week after-school curriculum for elementary school children consisting of hands-on activities and family observing nights.  The DSBK program has over 10,000 student contact hours in the 5 years the program has been running.  The program also provides numerous graduate student and postdoctoral volunteers involved in DSBK "real world" training in education.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Star formation is one of the most important processes in determining the properties of the universe we live in.  This NSF program used new capabilities of the Atacama Large Millimeter Array and the Jansky Very Large Array to advance our knowledge of the most extreme star formation events in the universe ? the creation of ?super star clusters?, allowing us to investigation of the environments in which super star cluster are formed.

With the support of this NSF award we were able to:

1) Quantify the star formation efficiencies of these extreme star-forming regions. We used ALMA observations combined with HST images to combine the age and stellar mass of star clusters in the Antennae galaxies with measurements of their gas mass. We find that very few clusters are formed with sufficiently high efficiency to remain bound, and by ages of 106.7 years, some clusters will have lost all of their associated molecular gas, and by 107.5 years this is true for the majority of clusters. This work is published in graduate student Allison Matthew?s paper (Matthews et al. 2018)

2) Codify the relationship between molecular line strengths and ratios and cluster evolution. Using ALMA and SMA observations of the galaxy Henize 2-10, we probed the molecular environments of natal and young super star clusters. The molecular line ratios of regions containing the natal star clusters are different from the line ratios observed for regions elsewhere in the galaxy, and the line ratios appears to be correlated with the evolutionary stage of the clusters.

3) Constrain the physical environments required to form super star clusters.  Using 0.?1 resolution observations with ALMA of a suite of molecular lines, we were able to resolve the size of a proto-super star cluster molecular cloud, and determine its mass, temperature, and density structure. The relative line strengths of HCN and HCO+ in this region also suggest that these molecular lines can be used as a tracer for the evolutionary stage of a cluster. This work is published in graduate student Molly Finn?s paper (Finn et al. 2019, under review).

4) Train a graduate students in millimeter and radio science and techniques. In the projects described above, two graduate students received in-depth experience with the tools and techniques necessary to carry out this science program. Both students published first-author papers as a result of their work on this project. 

5) Support science literacy in our most rural communities. This program helped to support six week-long summer camps at rural locations around the state of Virginia run by the Dark Skies Bright Kids program (directed by the PI). Through these camps, nearly 100 children have participated in a custom hands-on curriculum based on fun, hands-on activities, with a specific themes in each unit (comets, rockets, light, etc), and aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS).   

 

 


Last Modified: 01/26/2019
Modified by: Kelsey E Johnson
